awd_titl_txt: Isotope Ecology and Paleoecology in East Africa in the Past 4 Ma
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this funded project is to study how diets of the major mammal groups in East Africa have changed over the past 4 million years. The project will use stable isotopes and tooth morphology, which evolves in response to diet preference, to understand changes to diet over time. This project will provide insight into the evolutionary processes that relate diet to tooth morphology, and it will provide a better understanding of how to use isotopes to interpret diet in humans and other mammals. This project includes a strong team of international collaborators, an education and outreach program that will link students in Utah with students in Kenya, and will contribute to understanding dietary evolution at ecological timescales. 

In East Africa, where early humans evolved, stable isotopes provide an important tool that can be used to study how diets have changed over time. Previous work has shown that the modern dietary preferences for some mammalian groups is quite different than their most closely related ancestors. By using modern observations and working in the controlled environments of zoos, it will be possible to better quantify the diet-tissue-isotope relationship that is related to physiology (e.g., hindgut versus foregut digestion). In addition, carbon isotopes will be used to study grazing versus browsing preferences, and Mg-isotopes will be used to study trophic structure. Further, the research components of the project are strongly integrated with the broader impacts goals of the project, and students will learn how to use isotopes to study dietary preferences and spatial variation between different domestic animals (e.g., goats, sheep, cattle) from different regions.

por.por_cntn:
In this project we were studying the diet history of mammals with applications to both modern ecosystems and to the fossil record.  We showed that digestive strategy (for example ruminants versus non-ruminants) has an important role in how foods are digested and how that is recorded in animal tissues, especially tooth enamel.  Methane production in ruminants is important in understanding this process. Results from these observations will be important in interpreting stable isotope data in studies of modern ecology and paleontology.

In applying our isotope studies to the fossil record, we find that elephants were grass consumers from 8 million years ago to about 100,000 years ago when they switched to a diet comprised of leaves and shrubs.   The implications of this diet change is significant for the understanding of savanna ecosystems because elephants are considered to be a keystone species, whose behavior modifies the growth and competition between trees and grasses.  Other important ecological changes occurred about 100,000 years ago, such as the extinction of the grazing pig Kolpochoerus and its replacement its close relative, the browsing Hylochoerus.  The causes for these important ecological changes, about the time that anatomically modern humans appeared in the fossil record, remains unknown.

For broader impacts, we initiated a collaboration with the educational NGO WildlifeDirect to start a citizen science project with school children in Kenya. Hair samples from domestic livestock, such as goats, from their home farms can be used to characterize strontium isotope values that are determined by the local geological substrate.  Using that data we can produce strontium "IsoScapes" that relate strontium isotope values to local geology.  This will have immediate applications in archaeology, animal migration studies, and forensics.
